DOC.brief_summary: This small feasibility study will evaluate the use of hydrogel electrode pads (rather than tap water baths) to deliver iontophoresis treatment using a traditional iontophoresis device. Participants will treat one hand with the hydrogel-based iontophoresis device and leave the other hand untreated.
DOC.brief_title: Management of Palmar Hyperhidrosis With Hydrogel-based Iontophoresis
DOC.detailed_description: Palmar hyperhidrosis affects 4.3 million Americans and results in substantial quality of life impairment. Treatment options for palmar hyperhidrosis include antiperspirants, systemic anticholinergic agents, botulinum toxin injections, and iontophoresis. Standard iontophoresis involves submerging the hands in tap water through which current is applied to the palms for 30 minutes per day up to 3 times per week. While effective, treatment adherence rates are low. This is a small feasibility study to evaluate the use of hydrogel electrode pads (rather than tap water baths) to deliver iontophoresis treatment using a traditional iontophoresis device. Hydrogel electrode pads permit improved mobility and hand functionality during iontophoresis treatment sessions.
DOC.criteria: 18 years of age or older Selfreported >6 months history of hyperhidrosis Initial gravimetry test sweat production of >20mg/min/palm No antiperspirant use on the palms for 2 weeks prior to study enrollment No use of systemic treatments for hyperhidrosis (anticholinergics) for 4 weeks prior to study enrollment No use of tap water iontophoresis for 6 weeks prior to study enrollment No Botox injections on the palms for 6 or 10 months prior to study enrollment for prospective participants who have undergone 1 or multiple Botox treatments, respectively No history of cardiothoracic sympathectomy Able to attend 3 clinical visits during the study period Capable of performing sweat level testing and hydrogelbased iontophoresis treatment at home (after training) Individuals with implanted electronic medical devices (e.g. pacemaker, implantable cardioverter/defibrillator, metalcontaining intrauterine device) Individuals with metal implants in the extremity to be treated Individuals with skin defects (on the palm or forearm of the extremity to be treated) that cannot be covered by petroleum jelly Women who are pregnant or nursing Individuals on medications that interfere with neuroglandular transmission Individuals with active infection locally on the extremity to be treated or systemically Individuals with history of contact dermatitis to acrylates or iodine Individuals with history of systemic allergy to iodine Individuals with a history of ischemic heart disease, cardiac arrhythmias, epilepsy, or thyroid disease
